ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to evaluate a study with a keen eye, as well as how to apply research from various different fields to morality.
I got much better at efficiently reading and digesting complex cognitive science papers.
I gained a good overview of the connection between morality and cognitive science.
Critical thinking skills about many of the puzzles in moral psychology. A better understanding of your own moral compass and its nuances

This seminar surveyed the fascinating literature of morality descriptively arises from how the human mind. More importantly though, by in Prof Knobe's helpful guiding of a debate-like (but chill) class discussion, I also learned how to think critically about how evidence might or might not support theories in social science. Finally, devised as an assignment to produce a piece of original work in this domain, the final project taught me a lot about model-building in the social sciences.
I gained a solid grasp of the main elements and theories of moral psychology, which I believe will apply well to my future courses and work.
Knowledge and practical learning of the topic

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think varying up the assignments could be cool. Especially towards the end of the semester, people were not as engaged with discussion because the only real assessment is the final paper. While it's a cool project, it would be fun to engage in smaller ways with more ideas.

I genuinely do not see any weaknesses with the course. The strengths are endless -- the final project was engaging and fun, professor Knobe always made himself available for help, and the readings were interesting.

This course could be demanding in terms of the requirements for the final project and the amount of critical thinking used in classbut I consider this one of its greatest strengths. I really had to THINK in this class.

Strengths: 1. Prof Knobe is an amazing human and a fantastic seminar leading. The fact that he's one of the pioneers of the domain of the class is only the icing on the cake. 2. The material itself is intuitive enough to be easy to grasp, yet complex enough to motivate a lot of thought (and self-reflection). 3. The only assignment is the final paper, which makes the class pretty low on workload. Weaknesses: 1. Perhaps the fact that there were no graded assignments made the final project a little stressful.

A strength is that it was a really collaborative space in which students were able to freely share their thoughts. I really appreciated how students' comments were all responded to in some degree by either other students or the professor.
Great discussion and range of topics

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student who is deeply interested in the Cognitive Science of Morality. I'd imagine the course would feel draining to someone with even modest interest in the topics we discuss.

If you want a challenging course where you will have to seriously consider the processes behind moral judgements, this is for you. I did not realize how nuanced morality was until this course and I'll take what I learned with me through life

If you're interested in what different forces and intuitions might drive you to particular moral conclusions, this is the course for you. It's a fantastically organized seminar, led by one of the best professors at Yale, who just happens to be a leading author in this field too.
Yes, especially for students who enjoy self-driven learning that is guided and shaped by a professor instead of being strictly directed.
